text:
A General View of Manhattan and the Hudson River, looking in a North Westerly direction, from Clarkson Street and Broadway.

1889.

Brown Brothers, Photographers,
1482 Broadway,
title: General view - [Downtown Manhattan and Hudson River.]

text:
W. 42nd Street, north side, from Broadway (right) to Seventh Avenue (left) showing the triangular site of the present Times Building. The ornate building shown is inscribed "Charles Thorley, A. D. 1896." At the left is Oscar Hammersteins "Victoria".

May 11, 1900

Gift of Urbrock Collection
H. N. Tiemann, photo

West 42nd Street, north side, between Broadway (right) and Seventh Ave. (left), showing a triangular excavation extending to 43rd Street, that is today (1937) occupied by the Times Building. This clearance was created by the demolition of 6, 4-story houses, which bore Nos. 1469 to 1485 Broadway and 603 to 619 Seventh Ave. This area is now known as Times Square.

December 4, 1901.

Broadway, west side, south from 43rd Street, showing also a view south on Seventh Avenue. In the centre is the Pabst Hotel. Within two years this will be demolished, and the New York Times Building erected on the site.

1902.

H. N. Tiemann Co.

Broadway, west side, from 42nd to 45th Streets. At the left, construction work on the New York Times Building is under way. At 43rd Street is the Hotel Cadillac, and above it is Rector's, which, along with the corner building at 44th Street, will soon be replaced by the Hotel Claridge. From 44th to 45th Streets are the Criterion and New York theatres. The building which they occupy, which at the time of this picture is called the Crystal Gardens, will be demolished in 1935. Broadway is badly torn up from subway construction, which is nearly completed. 1903.

Brown Brothers.

Broadway, north from W. 43rd Street (intersection at right foreground) showing the open area formed by the crossing of this thoroughfare and Seventh Avenue and known as Times Square. Prominently seen is the Hotel Astor. To the left of same are brownstone structures where the 6 story Putnam Building was later erected. Today (1938) the huge Paramount Building occupies this site. Note the sole automobile and street car. To the right is the New York Theatre.

December 1905.

Geo. L. Balgue,

Broadway, east side, from 43rd to 45th Streets. The Hotel Cadillac, after remodeling, will for a while be called the Wallick, but its original name will soon be restored. Rector's, a famous restaurant of the fin du siècle days, will soon be replaced, along with the corner building at 44th Street, by the Hotel Claridge. In the next block, from 44th to 45th Streets, is the New York Theatre, which also houses the Criterion Theatre. This building will be torn down in 1935.

May, 1909.

Brown Brothers.

Broadway, west side, south from and including 43rd Street, showing also the west side of Seventh Avenue, south from 43rd Street. In the centre is the second building of the New York Times, built in 1904. This building caused the name of the region bounded by Broadway and Seventh Avenue from 42nd to 47th Streets to be changed from Longacre Square to Times Square. The Times was formerly located at 41 Park Row, and in the middle 1920's will move to 43rd Street west of Seventh Avenue.

1909.

Wurts Brothers.
42nd Street at the S.E. corner of Broadway. About 1915.

Crowds in Times Square, New York City, on election night, waiting for returns.
Nov. 1916
International Films Service

Broadway at the N.E. corner of 42nd Street. What would have been a good northward view of Broadway is blocked by the subway kiosk.

About 1921.

Gift of E. M. Jenks.

West 42nd street, north side, west from and including Broadway, to and including Seventh Ave. Prominent building shown is the Times Building. A general view north is also shown.

About 1924.

Ewing Galloway.

1493-1505 Broadway, west side, from West 43rd (left) to 44th (right) Streets, showing the 6-story Putnam Building that today (1937) has been replaced by the mammoth Paramount Building. Shown on the left and west of a row of 4-story structures (Nos. 207 to 215 inclusive) is the 4 and 11-story Times Annex. On the right appears a corner of the Hotel Astor. This area is known as Times Square, though the buildings bear Broadway numbers.

About 1925.

Brown Brothers.

140 West 42nd Street adjoining the S.E. corner of Broadway. Shown is the street level only of the Coral Gables Building that was devoted to sales of “Floridian” property of that name near Miami. About 1926

42nd Street, north side, west from Broadway, showing the Times Building in the foreground.

1926.

Brown Brothers.

Broadway, east side, north from 42nd Street. In the foreground are the Longacre and Fitzgerald Buildings, and the entrance to the George M. Cohan Theatre. In the next block are the Hotels Cadillac and Claridge, and above them the Criterion and New York theatres. At the extreme left is the Hotel Astor.
1926.

Brown Brothers.

Broadway, at W. 44th Street as viewed northwestward from the Bush Terminal Building on 42nd Street. This location appears in the center of the view and shows at the S.W., the N.W. and the S.E. corners respectively, the Paramount Building, the Hotel Astor and the Hotel Claridge. In the foreground appears W. 43rd Street with the 12 story Cadillac Hotel to the east of Times Square. Adjacent to same and only 6 stories in height is the Hotel Yates.

P.L. Sperr

Astor Hotel in daytime. 1926
Astor Hotel at Midnight

March 18, 1929.

The New York Times Building, Broadway, west side, from 42nd to 43rd Streets. At the right is the Paramount Building and Theatre. About 1927.

Ewing Galloway.

The Fitzgerald Building, Broadway at the S.E. corner of 43rd Street.

August 9, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

South on Seventh Avenue, from the Paramount Theatre, at 43rd Street. About 1929.
Photograph by Ewing Galloway.

241-247 West 43rd Street, north side, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues: an old apartment house called Yandis Court.
June 10, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

1491-1485 Broadway, at, adjoining and south of the S.W. corner of West 43rd Street. This section of Times Square is technically Seventh Ave., with Broadway numbers.

July 25, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

The Hotels Cadillac and Claridge, Broadway, east side, from 43rd to 44th Streets.
February 5, 1929.

General View Midtown Manhattan, Bryant Park area: Looking northeastward across Bryant Park and 42nd Street from Broadway at 38th Street. On the left is the Worlds Tower Building (white) and across the park is the low Stern Brothers Department Store. The buildings in the center background (from left to right) are: the Fred F. French Building, Salmon Tower, Lefcourt National Building and New York Central Building.

View 2 is in a more northerly direction.

P. L. Sperr

August 18, 1929
View 1,2
title: General view - Midtown Manhattan - [Bryant Park.]

text:
General View Midtown Manhattan, East 30's: The two views are southeastward from 42nd Street near Broadway and show the Empire State Building under construction and the more distant Metropolitan Life tower.

View 3 is south from Radio City, across the East 40's and East 30's. The Empire State and Metropolitan Life towers are in the right background. Other buildings, from left to right, are: Chanin, Lincoln, Lefcourt-Colonial (spires), 2° East 40th Street, 10 East 40th Street, and 500 Fifth Avenue.

P. L. Sperr

View 1,2: July 30, 1930
View 3: August 9, 1933

view 1 - Neg. # 1478
view 2
title: General view - Midtown Manhattan - East 30s

text:
43rd Street, north side, from Eighth to Seventh Avenues. In the foreground a couple of nuns are crossing Eighth Avenue.
June 4, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

Broadway, east side, south from 43rd Street. The tall, white building is the 43-story Continental Building, which replaced the old Hotel Continental.

October 1, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

The Hotel Cadillac, Broadway at the N.E. corner of 43rd Street.  Originally called by its present name, this hotel was known as the Hotel Wallace from about 1911 to about 1916.
June 28, 1933
P.L. Sperr

Seventh Avenue at N.W. corner of 43rd Street, showing the main entrance to the Paramount Theatre.

March 1934.

Gift of Eric Christiansen, Photographer.

Steuben Tavern, 42nd Street, south side, from Broadway to Seventh Avenue. This is a very new restaurant as shown; it was established here shortly after the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment. The Lexington Avenue Steuben Tavern is older. 1934.

Martin Haggett, Photographer.
Gift of New York Times.

Paramount Building and Theatre, Seventh Avenue, west side, from 43rd to 44th Streets, taken from 145 West 45th Street. In the right foreground may be seen the Astor Hotel, at the N.W. corner of 44th Street.

August 4, 1935.

P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

West 42nd Street, south side, west from (No. 138; the Cameo Theatre) a point slightly east of Broadway and across same. The 15-story structure on the left is the former Knickerbocker Hotel that has been converted to business purposes. It bears Nos. 1462-1470 Broadway and stands at the S.E. corner of West 42nd Street. West of same appears a low structure occupying the apex of a triangular plot between Broadway and Seventh Ave. Progressing in the same direction one sees the 24-story Candler Building and the modern Graybar Building; the latter being between Eighth and Ninth Aves. This set consists of a negative and a positive view.

September 1935.

W.P.A. Photo.

West 42nd Street, south side, west from (No. 138; the Cameo Theatre) a point slightly east of Broadway and across same. The 15-story structure on the left is the former Knickerbocker Hotel that has been converted to business purposes. It bears Nos. 1462-1470 Broadway and stands at the S.E. corner of West 42nd Street. West of same appears a low structure occupying the apex of a triangular plot between Broadway and Seventh Ave. Progressing in the same direction one sees the 24-story Candler Building and the modern Graybar Building; the latter being between Eighth and Ninth Aves. This set consists of a negative and a positive view.

September 1935.

W.P.A. Photo.

Broadway (Times Square), at the N. E. corner of West 43rd Street, showing the Hotel Cadillac prior to demolition in 1940. At the left is the adjoining Hotel Claridge at 44th Street. In the foreground are the Police Information Booth and a subway kiosk.

The Hotel Cadillac was erected in two units. The first to rise was the eight story corner structure. This was built as the Barrett House in 1883. The adjoining unit rose several years later.and was the first to bear the name Cadillac. In 1900 they were combined. For a brief period between 1910 and 1915 they were known as the Hotel Wallick. The land upon which they stand has been owned by the Goelet interests, passing from Ogden Goelet to his daughter May, the wife of the Duke of Roxburghe, and to her son the present Duke.

For a more complete account see the New York Times of March 19, 1940.

July, 1935

George L. Balgue

Broadway, east side, north from but not including West 42nd Street.
September 26, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

Broadway (right) and Seventh Ave. (left), north from but not including West 43rd Street, showing Times Square during a drenching afternoon rain (3 P.M.). Note the automobiles with their headlights turned on and theatres with their electric signs lighted. This view is taken from the Times Building and appeared the following day, Tuesday July 13, 1937, in the New York Times.
July 12, 1937.

Gift of Wide World Photo Inc.

Times Square, north from West 42nd Street (Foreground) and showing mainly structures lining the east side of this intersecting point of Broadway and Seventh Ave. This is a set of 3 views, No. 2 of which is from West 43rd Street. No. 3 shows the new building on the east side of same, between 44th and 45th Streets that houses the Criterion Theatre and the International Casino. Atop same is the huge electric display sign of Wrigleys. For earlier views of this area, see the Broadway files.

September 14, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

Broadway (Times Square), at the N. E. corner of W. 43rd Street, showing the cleared site of the old Hotel Cadillac. At the left is a portion of the Hotel Claridge. W. 43rd Street is on the right and the view is eastward on the north side of same. Note the Hotel Woodstock there. It was outside of this structure that the famous Becker murder case (Rosenthal) was enacted.

View 1: June 17, 1940
View 2: August 23, 1940

P. L. Sperr

Broadway (Times Square), east side, south across W. 43rd Street, showing the changes at the two corners of same. The former Hotel Cadillac site is being cleared at the N. E. corner. The two story taxpayer opposite is occupied by Toffenetti's. This was formerly the site of the Fitzgerald Building and the George M. Cohan Theatre.
In the background are the towering buildings, No. 1450 Broadway, and the Bush Terminal.
